1 Introduction 0

Dielectrics (Polarizable Material)

When there is only one dipole in a constant electric field, it is easy to compute the modified electric field.

When there are many dipoles, each induced dipole modifies the total electric field, and the total electric field is what determines how large P is.

In response to an external electric field, Eo‚Äã, the molecules in a dielectric material reconfigure so as to produce a generally opposing electric field inside the material. In general, the electric field outside of the dielectric is also modified from Eo‚Äã.

This is similar to what happens in a conductor in an external electric field, with the difference being that in the conductor, free electrons can move to the surface of the conductor in such a way as to completely cancel the electric field inside the material. In a dielectric, electrons are bound and can only shift their position slightly. This shift creates an induced dipole. The large-scale electric field inside a dielectric material is the external electric field plus the electric field created by all of the induced dipoles.

There are two general types of dielectric materials:

  1. materials that have molecules that have no net electric field - these are referred to as non-polar molecules; and

  2. materials that have molecules that each have a net intrinsic electric field but are randomly oriented so on average the electric field is zero. These are referred to as polar molecules.

In simple dielectrics, the amount of polarization in a small volume is given by

P(x,y,z)=œµ0‚Äãœáe‚ÄãE(x,y,z)

where œáe‚Äã is a dimensionless proportionality constant and E is the net electric field at the location of the small volume.

In the following two examples, we give a physical justification for this equation for non-polar and polar dielectrics.

The interpretation of this equation is that in a given volume in the dielectric, the induced polarization is proportional to the electric field, E, at that location. The electric field at a given location in the material depends on the external electric field, Eo‚Äã, ‚Äò‚Äôand‚Äô‚Äô the electric field created by all of the other induced dipoles in the material. This fact makes the calculation of the electric field inside of a dielectric complicated. This complication is highlighted in an example below.

1.1 Mental Model for Non-Polar Dielectrics

At the atomic level, the creation of a dipole when an atom is exposed to an external electric field can be understood from a simple model of the atom.

1.2 Mental Model for Polar Dielectrics

A simple model for understanding polar molecules involves considering only the torque exerted on the polar molecule and ignoring the shift of the electron orbits considered for the non-polar molecule.

1.3 Calculation of Electric Field

It was noted that calculation of the net electric field inside and outside of a dielectric is complicated by the fact that at a given location the electric field is that due to external sources plus that due to all of the induced dipoles at other locations in the material. Here we give an example of how this could be handled mathematically. This is ‚Äò‚Äônot‚Äô‚Äô a good way of computing the electric field, but serves to justify the ‚Äúcomplicated‚Äù claim. This example is based on Example XX in Griffiths, 1989.

Asking a given location in a material to report on its polarization is akin to calling for a vote among a group of humans where everyone prefers to vote only after hearing how everyone else is going to vote.

P(x,y,z)=œµ0‚Äãœáe‚ÄãE(x,y,z)

2 Fundamental Dielectric Example

In reality, the ‚Äúpure‚Äù dipoles are not created by gluing dipoles into and onto an object - they are induced. The charges in an atom or molecule separate due to a local electric field and a dipole is induced. The dipole is ‚Äúbound‚Äù in the sense that the charges that make up the dipole are bound to the atom or molecule.

An external electric field, Eext‚Äã=Eext‚Äãx^ is created by two non-conducting sheets of charge.

A dielectric slab is placed between the sheet.

Find Eb‚Äã and E inside the dielectric slab assuming that the dipole density induced in the slab depends on the electric field in the slab according to P=œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãE, where E is the total electric field, which is due to the induced bound charge densities and the external electric field.

The result is E=1+œáe‚Äã1‚ÄãEext‚Äãx^. The key steps are

E=Eext‚Äã+Eb‚Äã

P=œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãE

The key to this problem is realizing that P depends directly on E in this way and not on Eext‚Äã. That is, P depends on the electric field due to both bound charges that are induced and external charges (the charges on the sheets).

œÉb‚Äã‚â°P‚ãÖn^=œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^

On the right/left face of the dielectric n^=¬±x^, so the right/left face has a bound surface charge density of

œÉb‚Äã=¬±œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãE

The electric field due to the bound surface charge densities can be found by finding the electric field due to œÉb‚Äã on an infinite sheet of charge.

Inside the dielectric, the electric field Eb‚Äã, which is due to œÉb‚Äã, is Eb‚Äã=‚àí(œÉb‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)x^. Using œÉb‚Äã=¬±œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãE found above gives

Eb‚Äã=‚àíœáe‚ÄãEx^

Inside the dielectric, the total field is

E=Ex^=Eext‚Äã+Eb‚Äã=Eext‚Äãx^‚àíœáe‚ÄãEx^

Solving for E gives

E=1+œáe‚Äã1‚ÄãEext‚Äã

Note that if you solved this problem by (wrongly) assuming P=œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãE, you would have found

E=(1‚àíœáe‚Äã)Eext‚Äã(wrong answer)

To see why this is wrong, consider the physical implications of this equation when œáe‚Äã>1 (for example, for water).

5 Introduction

In Continuous Electric Dipole Distributions, the problem of finding the electric field due to an object that had a polarization P ‚Äúfrozen in‚Äù was considered.

The approach was to find the bound charge densities that result from this polarization. Then the electric field due to the bound charge densities was computed.

Consider an object that is unpolarized (P=0), but is placed in an external electric field, Eext‚Äã. In response to this electric field, atomic‚Äìsized dipoles will tend to form. Thes induced dipoles create an electric field, which called an induced electric field.

The total field is then

Etotal‚Äã=Eexternal‚Äã+Einduced‚Äã

By convention, we drop the ‚Äútotal‚Äù subscript and abbreviate ‚Äúexternal‚Äù as ‚Äúext‚Äù. Given that the induced field is can be computed from bound charge densities, we can use Eb‚Äã in place of Einduced‚Äã to emphasize this point. In this notation, we have

E=Eext‚Äã+Eb‚Äã

It is important to note that Eb‚Äã depends on E.

Without additional information, it is not possible to compute E ‚Äì we need to know how much P is generated given E. Once we have P, we can compute the bound charge densities and then Eb‚Äã.

For many materials, the relationship between P and E is linear:

P=œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãE

where the constant œáe‚Äã is the electric susceptibility.

A constant that often appears in induced polarization problems is œµo‚Äã(1+œáe‚Äã), which is called permittivity or the dielectric constant:

œµ‚â°œµo‚Äã(1+œáe‚Äã)

5.1 Example ‚Äì Infinite Slab

An object with an electric susceptibility of œáe‚Äã is in the region ‚à£z‚à£‚â§t. The object is infinite in extent in the x and y directions.

There is an external electric field of Eo‚Äãz^.

Find E

Answer

E=Eext‚Äã+Eb‚Äã

Ez‚Äã=Eext z‚Äã+Eb z‚Äã

Ez‚Äã=Eo‚Äã+Eb z‚Äã

At this point, Ez‚Äã and Eb z‚Äã are unknown. We know that Eb z‚Äã is related to Pz‚Äã, which is in turn related to Ez‚Äã.

The bound surface densities are œÉb‚Äã=¬±Pz‚Äã on the top/bottom surfaces of the slab. The polarization is related to Ez‚Äã by Pz‚Äã=œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãEz‚Äã, so œÉb‚Äã=¬±œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãEz‚Äã.

œÅb‚Äã=0. This can be seen by taking the divergence of both sides of E=Eext‚Äã+Eb‚Äã, which gives ‚àá‚ãÖE=0+œÅb‚Äã. Using œÅb‚Äã=‚àíœµo‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖP and P=œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãE results in œÅb‚Äã=0 and dEz‚Äã/dz=0, so the field inside of the dielectric is constant.

As a result of œÉb‚Äã, the Eb z‚Äã=‚àíPz‚Äã/œµo‚Äã=‚àíœáe‚ÄãEz‚Äã in the slab and Eb z‚Äã=0 outside of the slab.

Thus, inside the slab

Ez‚Äã=Eo‚Äã+Eb z‚Äã=Eo‚Äã‚àíœáe‚ÄãEz‚Äã

Solving for Ez‚Äã gives

Ez‚Äã=1+œáe‚ÄãEo‚Äã‚Äã

Outside the slab, Ez‚Äã=Eo‚Äã.

Inside the slab, the induced polarization opposes the external electric field and causes the field to be smaller. Outside the slab, the induced electric field has no effect.

  1. Find and plot Ey‚Äã(y) if the slab has an electric susceptibility of œáe‚Äã=0.

5.3 Example ‚Äì Dielectric Around a Charged Sphere

In Example 4.5 of Griffiths, he finds the total electric field when a dielectric (polarizable material) is wrapped around a spherical shell with a net charge.

The total electric field is the sum of the field due to the induced polarization and the charges on the spherical shell.

Verify the equations for the total electric field stated in the solution to Example 4.5 by computing it using

E=Eb‚Äã+EQ‚Äã

where Eb‚Äã is the field due to the bound surface charge densities on the inner and outer surface of the dielectric, and EQ‚Äã is the field due to the charges on the surface of the sphere. Use the surface charge densities found in Example 4.5 for you calculations of the electric field.

Answer

Use Gauss‚Äôs law to find the electric field as a function of r due to three surface charges: œÉQ‚Äã=Q/4œÄa2 on a sphere of radius a, œÉbi‚Äã=‚àíœµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãQ/4œÄœµa2 at r=a, and œÉbo‚Äã=œµo‚Äãœáe‚ÄãQ/4œÄœµb2 at r=b

œÉQ‚Äã creates EQ‚Äã, which is zero for r<a and Q/4œÄœµo‚Äãr2 for r>a.

œÉbi‚Äã creates Ebi‚Äã, which is zero for r<a and 4œÄa2œÉbi‚Äã/4œÄœµo‚Äãr2 for r>a.

œÉbo‚Äã creates Ebo‚Äã, which is zero for r<b and 4œÄb2œÉbo‚Äã/4œÄœµo‚Äãr2 for r>b.

The sum of the fields due to the three surface charge densities Ebi‚Äã+Ebo‚Äã+EQ‚Äã gives E given in Example 4.5.

6.1 Dielectric Around a Charged Sphere

Hint: Inside the dielectric, the equation for E should depend on Er‚Äã(a), r, and constants. To finish the problem, one needs to solve for the unknown E(a). This can be done by setting r=a in the equation for E.

Answer

Inside the dielectric, the field is due to œÉb‚Äã(a)=‚àíP(a) and the uniform charge on the conducting surface. The net field inside is then

Er‚Äã(r)=kr2Q‚Äã+kr2œÉb‚Äã(a)4œÄa2‚Äã=kr2Q‚Äã‚àí4œÄœµo‚Äã1‚Äãr2P(a)4œÄa2‚Äã=kr2Q‚Äã‚àíœµo‚Äã1‚Äãr2P(a)a2‚Äã

To finish the problem, set r=a, solve for Er‚Äã(a), and then substitute the found value of Er‚Äã(a) into the above equation.

Setting r=a gives

Er‚Äã(a)=ka2Q‚Äã‚àíœáe‚ÄãEr‚Äã(a)‚áíEr‚Äã(a)=(1+œáe‚Äã)a2kQ‚Äã

Substitution into the equation above for Er‚Äã(r) gives

Note that the electric field is reduced in the dielectric (œáe‚Äã>0), as expected.

7 D and Gauss‚Äô Law for Dielectrics

8 Definition of D and Derivation of Gauss‚Äô Law for Dielectrics

We have shown that induced dipoles will form when an electric field exists in a dielectric. The electric field at a given location in the dielectric depends on the electric field due to all of the other dipoles and the external electric field. So, as it stands, to compute the electric field in a dielectric ‚Ä¶ you need to know the electric field in the dielectric.

One way of resolving this is to assume that the electric field in a dielectric is reduced by a factor of what it would have been if the dielectric was not there. This is only sometimes correct and is thus about as useful as the grammar rule ‚Äúi before e except after c‚Äù [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/06/28/the-i-before-e-except-after-c-rule-is-a-giant-lie/?utm_term=.ea1af8b230c3].

Gauss‚Äô Law can be used to find the correct answer for certain problems (the same types of problems where it is useful for calculating the electric field - problems with symmetry that allows simplification of the integral). More generally, special techniques are needed (Boundary Value Method and the Method of Images), both of which rely of Gauss‚Äô Law for dielectrics.

We being by first defining a new quantity related to E, the oddly named electric displacement or electric flux density*, D, which is also called the electric flux density,

D‚â°œµ0‚ÄãE+P

E is the electric field, which is due to external electric fields and the electric field of the induced dipoles. P is the polarization, which depends on E. We are combining two things that are difficult to calculate to define D, which perhaps unexpectedly, will be easier to calculate.

We also distinguish charges among those that are due to polarization, Qbound‚Äã, and the rest, Qfree‚Äã (again, naming choice could be clearer, but is standard):

Q=Qfree‚Äã+Qbound‚Äã

Next, write Gauss‚Äô Law in terms of D, P, Qfree‚Äã, and Qbound‚Äã:

Gauss‚Äô Law is

Œ¶E‚Äã‚â°‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖda=QInsideS‚Äã/œµ0‚Äã

substitution gives

‚àÆS‚Äã(D/œµ0‚Äã‚àíP/œµ0‚Äã)‚ãÖda=QFreeinsideS‚Äã/œµ0‚Äã+QBoundinsideS‚Äã/œµ0‚Äã

simplifying

‚àÆS‚ÄãD‚ãÖda‚àí‚àÆS‚ÄãP‚ãÖda=QFreeinsideS‚Äã+QBoundinsideS‚Äã

The second term on both sides of the equation are equal*, leaving

‚àÆS‚ÄãD‚ãÖda=QInsideSfree‚Äã

This is another form of Gauss‚Äô Law and is referred to here as Gauss‚Äô Law for dielectrics in integral form. It is also valid for non-dielectrics. In older textbooks, one often finds a discussion of electric displacement flux, Œ¶D‚Äã

Œ¶D‚Äã‚â°‚àÆS‚ÄãD‚ãÖda=QInsideSfree‚Äã

before the electric flux

Œ¶E‚Äã‚â°‚àÆS‚ÄãD‚ãÖda=QInsideS‚Äã

The equation for Œ¶D‚Äã looks similar to that for Œ¶E‚Äã, except that its right-hand side only refers to non-bound charges (‚Äúfree charges‚Äù) inside a surface and the factor of œµ0‚Äã is missing. The equations for Œ¶E‚Äã and Œ¶D‚Äã are equally valid, but Œ¶D‚Äã should be used for dielectrics as it simplifies the solution.

*Using œÉb‚Äã=P‚ãÖn^ and da‚â°n^da gives

‚àí‚àÆS‚ÄãP‚ãÖda=‚àí‚àÆS‚ÄãP‚ãÖn^da=‚àí‚àÆS‚ÄãœÉb‚Äãda

8.1 œÉb‚Äã refers to charges ‚Äò‚Äôon‚Äô‚Äô, but not inside of, a Gaussian surface. Because we are talking about dipoles, there must be an equal an opposite number of charges just below, and so inside, the Gaussian surface. So QBoundenclosed‚Äã=‚àí‚àÆS‚ÄãœÉb‚Äãda.

8.2 Historical Origin and Units on D

The units on electric displacement are

[D]=m2Coulomb‚Äã

whereas for electric field

[E]=CoulombNewtons‚Äã

In a sense, D is more natural quantity with regard to its units - because the units in its denominator are m2, it ‚Äò‚Äôseems‚Äô‚Äô like a quantity that you would want to integrate over an area. But then this leads to the awkward question of ‚ÄúFlux is usually a quantity fo ‚Äòstuff‚Äô flowing through a surface‚Äù. According to Gauss‚Äô Law for dielectrics, the ‚Äòstuff‚Äô has units of coulombs. But no actual charge flows through the surface?!‚Äù When the laws of electricity were being formulated, Faraday, Maxwell and others were very much influenced by the physics of fluid flow. The word ‚Äúflux‚Äù means flow. In Faraday‚Äôs 1837 experiment, he noted that it was if charge was induced on the outer sphere and was displaced by lines of force originating on the inner sphere. [https://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/Rarebook_treasures/QC503F211839_PDF/QC503F211839v2.pdf] [https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Page%3AA_Treatise_on_Electricity_and_Magnetism_-_Volume_1.djvu/100 First reference of Maxwell to ‚Äúdisplacement‚Äù]

See also http://www.jpier.org/PIER/pier149/17.14092503.pdf

This is one of the many reasons why E&M is conceptually difficult. Consider Lord Kelvin‚Äôs opinion: ‚ÄúThat is why I take plain dynamics. I can get a model in plain dynamics; I cannot in electromagnetics.‚Äù [http://zapatopi.net/kelvin/quotes/]. Also ‚ÄúI have not had a moment‚Äôs peace or happiness in respect to electromagnetic theory since Nov. 28 1846.‚Äù [https://books.google.com/books?id=mN0TDAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA229&ots=mlKk9PJkji&dq=Nov.%2028%201846%20Faraday%20publication&pg=PA229#v=onepage&q=Nov.%2028%201846%20Faraday%20publication&f=false]. See [https://books.google.com/books?id=kdm9nmAkKvIC&lpg=PA1015&dq=November%2028%201846%20kelvin&pg=PA1015#v=onepage&q=November%2028%201846%20kelvin&f=false] for the relevance of the date.‚Äù

8.3 Using Gauss‚Äô Law for Dielectrics

Here is how Gauss‚Äô Law has can be used to resolve the issue for certain types of problems. First, compute D using Gauss‚Äô Law for dielectrics. The charges in this version of the law refer to charges that we usually know about - their location and magnitude (this is the motivation for calling them ‚Äúfree‚Äù - we can freely, or at least more easily, modify their location and magnitude). Then, use P=œáe‚Äãœµ0‚ÄãE and the definition of D

D‚â°œµ0‚ÄãE+P=œµ0‚ÄãE+œáe‚Äãœµ0‚ÄãE

and solve for E

E=œµ0‚Äã(1+œáe‚Äã)D‚Äã

Another common way of writing this is

E=D/œµ

using the definition

œµ=‚â°œµ0‚Äã(1+œáe‚Äã)

œµ0‚Äãœµ‚Äã=œµr‚Äã‚â°(1+œáe‚Äã)

They are a measure of the magnitude of the dielectric permittivity relative to the permittivity of free space.

To complicate matters, some references use dielectric constant Œ∫ or relative permittivity Œ∫r‚Äã instead of œµ and œµr‚Äã.

8.5.1 Dielectric Between Sheets of Charge

Answer

Because we are treating sheets are infinite, the electric field does not depend on distance from the sheet and electric field is perpendicular to the sheet.   • x<‚àíd, E=0x^

  • ‚àíd<x<‚àíd, E=+œÉ0‚Äã/œµ0‚Äãx^

  • x>d, E=0x^

We expect the electric potential to be the highest near the positive sheet as this is the location where a positive test charge will have the highest potential energy. We are given the potential at x=0 - a reference potential must always be given or specified because differences in potential are what determine physical quantities of interest. We can approach this problem in two ways:

  1. Ask what V would give the correct E when we use E=‚àí‚àáV=‚àíx^‚àÇV/‚àÇx

  2. Use ŒîV=‚àí‚à´ab‚ÄãE‚ãÖdl

From 1., we conclude that V must be linear with a negative slope of œÉ0‚Äã/œµ0‚Äã between the sheets and it must be constant (and not necessarily zero) outside of the sheets. The given V(0)=0 give the intercept as 0. The electric potential must be continuous and it does not change for x<‚àíd and x>d because the electric field is zero. So for x<‚àíd, the potential must be the same as it is at x=‚àíd and similar for x>d. These considerations give

  • x<‚àíd, V=œÉ0‚Äãd/œµ0‚Äã

  • ‚àíd<x<‚àíd, V=‚àíœÉ0‚Äãx/œµ0‚Äã

  • x>d, V=‚àíœÉ0‚Äãd/œµ0‚Äã

The second approach is to use Œ¥V=V(b)‚àíV(a)=‚àí‚à´ab‚ÄãE‚ãÖdl in the different regions. In all regions, dl=x^dx. Choosing a=0 and b=x, we have

ŒîV=V(b)‚àíV(a)=V(x)‚àíV(0)=‚àí‚à´0x‚Äã+œÉ0‚Äã/œµ0‚Äãx^‚Ä≤‚ãÖx^‚Ä≤dx‚Ä≤=‚àíœÉ0‚Äãx/œµ0‚Äã

where x^‚ãÖx^=1 has been used and the dummy integration variable was set to x‚Ä≤. Since V(0)=0, we have, V(x)=‚àíœÉ0‚Äãx/œµ0‚Äã, which applies only to the region for which E=+œÉ0‚Äã/œµ0‚Äãx^. This equation can be used to find V(d)=‚àíœÉ0‚Äãd/œµ0‚Äã and V(‚àíd)=œÉ0‚Äãd/œµ0‚Äã. To find the potential for x>d, we can use

ŒîV=V(x)‚àíV(d)=‚àí‚à´dx‚Äã0x^‚Ä≤‚ãÖx^‚Ä≤dx‚Ä≤=0

so that V(x)=V(d) for x>d. Similarily, for x<‚àíd

ŒîV=V(x)‚àíV(‚àíd)=‚àí‚à´‚àídx‚Äã0x^‚Ä≤‚ãÖx^‚Ä≤dx‚Ä≤=0

giving V(x)=V(‚àíd)=œÉ0‚Äãd/œµ0‚Äã.

Note that I accepted E=0 as an answer in case you were assuming that the charge on the outer shell equaled the charge on the inner shell, which is a common type of problem and easy to miss if you are working quickly.

8.5.6 Dielectrics around a Point Charge

A positive point charge is at the origin. Three spherical dielectrics are also centered on the origin. They have

  1. Inner radius a, outer radius 2a, and œµ=2œµo‚Äã

  2. Inner radius 2a, outer radius 3a, and œµ=4œµo‚Äã

  3. Inner radius 3a, outer radius 4a, and œµ=2œµo‚Äã

Sketch the electric field as a function of distance from the origin. You do not need to add labels for amplitudes on the electric field axis.

8.5.7 Dielectric Between Spherical Shells of Charge

8.5.8 General Rule for Computing E?

You may find after solving a few dielectric problems using Gauss‚Äô Law that it seems as if the electric field in the dielectric is always simply Eindielectric‚Äã=Eo‚Äã/œµr‚Äã, where Eo‚Äã is the electric field that would exist if the dielectric was not there.

For elementary problems involving dielectrics, this is often true. For example:

  1. One or more large square dielectrics between two large sheets of charge

  2. One or more large square dielectrics between two large capacitor plates ‚Äò‚Äô‚Äôafter‚Äô‚Äô‚Äô they are disconnected from a battery (so problem is equivalent to 1.)

    1. and 2. for one or more dielectrics between two co-aligned and long cylindrical shells

    1. and 2. for one or more dielectrics between two co-aligned and spherical shells

Incidentally, 1.-4. are all problems for which Gauss‚Äô Law for dielectrics can be used to find D and E.

In general, however, Eindielectric‚ÄãÓÄ†=Eo‚Äã/œµr‚Äã. Two examples:

  1. A large square dielectric between large capacitor plates that are held at a constant potential, Vo‚Äã. The presence of the dielectric causes the amount of charge on the capacitor plates to increase. The electric field in the dielectric is Eo‚Äã/? and not Eo‚Äã/œµ, where Eo‚Äã=Vo‚Äã/d is the electric field that existed before. This problem is covered in the section on capacitors with dielectrics.

  2. A spherical dielectric in a constant electric field, Eo‚Äã. In this situation, the induced polarization adds up in a way so that the net electric field is Eo‚Äã/? instead of Eo‚Äã/œµ inside the dielectric. This problem is covered in the section on boundary value problems with dielectrics.
